Affiliated Hospital of Kunming Medical University 650032 Kunming Yunnan China * guoxiaobing2002@163.com * why0209@hotmail.com * liping@kmmu.edu.cn 18 9 2025 30 9 2025 10 38 498176 43379 43390 30 6 2025 09 9 2025 03 9 2025 18 9 2025 18 09 2025 03 10 2025 03 10 2025 © 2025 The Authors. Published by American Chemical Society 2025 The Authors https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This article is licensed under CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 Traumatic brain injury
(TBI), characterized by structural brain
damage caused by external physical shocks, is a significant global
health challenge. Autophagy plays an important role in the cellular
self-protection mechanism during its pathological progression. Traditional
Chinese medicine (TCM) has a long history and unique advantages in
neuroprotection. This review summarizes the key markers of autophagy
and the relevant signaling pathways involved in autophagy in TBI,
mainly including the PI3K/Akt/mTOR, AMPK/mTOR, Nrf2, TLR4 signaling
pathways, and the endoplasmic reticulum stress autophagy axis. In
addition, this paper summarizes the recent advances in TCM approaches
in TBI autophagy treatment, such as terpenoids, flavonoids, polyphenols,
alkaloids, and carotenoids, which are active components of TCM, as
well as acupuncture nonpharmacological therapies. (TBI) refers to structural neurological
damage resulting from direct or indirect application of external mechanical
trauma to the head, which can lead to behavioral changes and cognitive
decline, making it difficult for patients to return to normal life. Autophagy is a mechanism of defense and stress regulation that
has important roles in the cellular growth and development, innate
and adaptive immunity, programmed cell death, and the maintenance
of internal environmental homeostasis.    Traditional Chinese medicine
(TCM) has a long history and unique
advantages in neuroprotection. Its multitarget and multipathway therapeutic
features provide new ideas and methods for the regulation strategies
of neurological diseases. In recent years, studies have shown that
active ingredients such as saponins, flavonoids, and alkaloids in
TCM have significant multitarget advantages in neuroprotective mechanisms
and can improve neurological function through various pathways such
as antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, modulation of signaling pathways,
and promotion of neuroplasticity.  vitro In summary, TCM has significant advantages in the treatment
of
TBI as well as regulating autophagy. In this study, autophagy’s
pivotal involvement in TBI was discussed in depth, and the modulatory
effects of the natural active ingredients in TCM and traditional therapies
(e.g., acupuncture) on TBI were systematically summarized, further
analyzing the mechanism of TCM intervention in TBI by targeting autophagy
and its principle of action. 2 Classification and Process
of Autophagy Autophagy, defined as “self-eating”
at the subcellular
level, was initially proposed in 1962.  mTOR is a key regulator of autophagy, and its mechanism of action
is mainly through the regulation of the ULK1 complex, which includes
ULK1, ATG13, FIP200, and ATG101. During nutrient-replete states, mTOR
sustains autophagic suppression by phosphorylating the ULK1 complex. Figure 1 Mechanisms of autophagy
after a traumatic brain injury. 3 Autophagy Signaling Pathway in TBI The pathological
mechanism of TBI is complex, involving multiple
autophagy related pathways. Here, we will focus on introducing the
PI3K/Akt/mTOR, AMPK/mTOR, Nrf2, TLR4 signaling pathways and the endoplasmic
reticulum stress-autophagy axis, and explore their potential roles
in the dynamic imbalance of autophagy after TBI. The mechanism diagram
of autophagy in TBI is shown in Figure 3.1 PI3K/Akt/mTOR The PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling
pathway, as a key regulatory pathway of cellular autophagy, is also
an important link in the pathological process of TBI. PI3K is composed
of regulatory subunit p85 and catalytic subunit p110, and its activity
is regulated by growth factor receptors such as EGFR.  3.2 AMPK/mTOR AMPK
is a cellular energy
sensor and regulator that maintains intracellular homeostasis by modulating
cellular metabolism and energy balance.  3.3 Nrf2 Nrf2, as a transcription factor,
can regulate the expression of genes encoding detoxifying enzymes,
antioxidant enzymes, and drug transporters.  in vivo  3.4 TLR4 TLR4 initiates the host innate
immune response by specifically conjugating LPS components in the
bacterial outer membranes.  3.5 ER Stress-Autophagy Axis The endoplasmic
reticulum (ER) is an important organelle for protein synthesis, protein
structure folding, and calcium ion storage in eukaryotic cells. TBI
can cause many complications, such as peroxidation, ischemia and hypoxia,
energy deficiency, or inflammatory reactions, causing changes in the
internal environment of the endoplasmic reticulum, leading to imbalance
of Ca 2+  4 Chinese Herbal Active Ingredients Regulate TBI
through Autophagy In recent years, the research value of
TCM in the treatment of
neurological diseases has become increasingly prominent. TCM contains
a variety of active ingredients, such as terpenoids, flavonoids, polyphenols,
and alkaloids, which exhibit significant pharmacological activities.
Especially for neurological diseases, active ingredients of TCM can
improve neurological function by regulating autophagy-related signaling
pathways, exerting antioxidative stress, anti-inflammatory, and apoptosis
effects. Moreover, Chinese medicine therapy has a multitarget synergistic
effect, which can act on multiple links and targets of the nervous
system at the same time, and this multipathway intervention makes
Chinese medicine more advantageous in the treatment of neurological
disorders that are complex and have various pathological mechanisms.
Therefore, here we summarize the application of TCM in neurological
diseases, especially TBI. The active ingredients of TCM treat TBI
through autophagy, as shown in Table 1 Mechanism of TCM Active Ingredients
Intervening in TBI through Autophagy 4.1 Terpenoids The active components
of boswellia sacra gum resin (BSR) are mainly pentacyclic triterpenoids.
It was found that BSR could activate the AMPK/Beclin-1 signaling pathway
to enhance the conversion of LC3-II, an autophagy marker, and increase
the accumulation of p62, which synergistically regulated apoptosis
and exerted neuroprotective effects. Ginsenoside-Rb1 (GS-Rb1) belongs to the triterpenoid saponin class
of terpenes and is a typical ginseng active ingredient. It has been
found that GS-Rb1 can protect neurons and reduce cell death by inhibiting
excessive autophagy. The active components of Panax notoginseng Panax notoginseng Panax notoginseng Panax notoginseng Panax notoginseng 4.2 Flavonoids Hydroxysafflor yellow
A (HSYA) is an active ingredient extracted from the TCM safflower,
which belongs to the chalcone glycoside class of flavonoid compounds. Morin, a natural flavonoid, is widely found in mulberry trees
and other plants, and in recent years it has been found to have significant
neuroprotective effects. Baicalin, as the main active ingredient of TCM Scutellaria
baicalensis Quercetin is a common flavonoid widely found
in many herbal medicines.
According to reports, quercetin exerts neuroprotective effects by
enhancing the permeability of the BBB and increasing its bioavailability
in the brain. 4.3 Polyphenols Resveratrol is a naturally
occurring polyphenolic compound with potent antioxidant properties
that is widely distributed in dietary sources such as grape skins,
berry fruits, grains, and red wine.   Curcumin is a polyphenolic compound extracted
from turmeric, family Zingiberaceae, and has a variety of pharmacological
effects. Curcumin activates the PI3K/AKT and AMPK signaling pathways
to promote neuronal survival and metabolic homeostasis, while inhibiting
the JNK/NF-κB/Akt signaling pathway to reduce neuroinflammation.  Bisdemethoxycurcumin (BDMC) is a derivative of curcumin and belongs
to the polyphenolic compound. Studies have reported that BDMC can
enhance the killing effect of cisplatin on cancer cells by inducing
cellular autophagy, making cancer cells more sensitive to cisplatin
treatment. 4.4 Alkaloids Tetrandrine is a bisbenzylisoquinoline
alkaloid isolated from Stephania tetrandra 4.5 Carotenoid Crocetin is an active
constituent extracted from the stigma of the Chinese herbal medicine
saffron and belongs to the family of carotenoid derivatives. It has
multiple properties such as anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and neuroprotective,
and is widely used in the treatment of central nervous system diseases. 5 Acupuncture Regulates TBI
through Autophagy Acupuncture, as a nonpharmacological therapy,
regulates nerve function
by stimulating specific acupuncture points without the need for surgical
or pharmacological intervention. This noninvasive property makes it
highly safe in the treatment of TBI, especially for patients who cannot
tolerate surgery or medication. Several studies have shown that acupuncture
can improve functional recovery after TBI. For example, acupuncture
regulates cerebral blood flow, reduces inflammatory responses, promotes
nerve regeneration, and improves cognitive function and emotional
state.   Wu et al. Neuronal autophagy
has a dynamic regulatory effect after acupuncture
intervention in TBI. Zhao et al. Although acupuncture has demonstrated multiple
advantages in TBI
treatment, it still faces many limitations and challenges. There are
fewer studies related to acupuncture in TBI autophagy, and the molecular
mechanisms have not been fully elucidated. The selection of acupuncture
points, stimulation parameters (e.g., frequency and intensity of electroacupuncture),
and treatment course of acupuncture for TBI have not yet been standardized,
which may lead to unstable efficacy. In addition, acupuncture is not
suitable for all stages or types of TBI, and data on long-term prognosis
are limited; more exploration is still needed. 6 Limitations
and Future Directions of TCM TCM plays a role in the treatment
of TBI mainly through a variety
of modalities such as herbal medicine and its active ingredients,
acupuncture, and electroacupuncture. However, although these methods
have shown some efficacy in animal experiments, more clinical studies
are needed to verify their effectiveness and safety.  7 Conclusion Autophagy
plays an important role in TBI and is involved in various
cellular and molecular processes. In this review article, we summarize
the mechanisms of autophagy in TBI and the role of TCM in regulating
autophagy in TBI. These findings support the importance of the autophagy
pathway in TBI, making autophagy an attractive therapeutic target
for the development of new therapeutic strategies for TBI. However,
TCM treatment of TBI still faces many challenges. How to organically
combine TCM theories with modern medicine to establish a more standardized
diagnosis and treatment is also an important direction for future
research. YC: Conceptualization,
